awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms and Processing Strategies for Sn Whisker Mitigation
awd_abstract_narration:
The growth of tin whiskers on fine pitched tin-plated electrical interconnect lines poses catastrophic short circuit problems in lead-free electronic components. In the past, this problem was mitigated by adding a few percent lead, which is no longer permissible due to a world-wide ban on lead. This research is aimed at developing robust strategies for mitigating tin-whisker growth by two different mechanisms. One path proposed is to alter the plating chemistry by adding dopants in the electroplating bath to emulate mechanisms that enable lead to impart whisker growth resistance to tin. Another is to modify deposition conditions to promote a near-equiaxed grain structure instead of typically prevalent columnar grains, allowing absorption of mass flow without whisker growth. To achieve this, the project will integrate an intellectual component of alloy-design/microstructure with a deliverable manufacturing component. To aid alloy-design, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations will be performed to provide insight into the influence of dopant elements on grain boundary energy and diffusivity in tin. The expected outcomes will be stress reduction in the tin plating as well as insight into the key mechanisms of whisker formation, including the impact of process conditions on the size and density of whiskers produced.

If successful, the process technology proposed here will have significant impact on the electronics manufacturing industry. The results will be particularly relevant for the power, space and military electronics industries, where lifetimes are measured in decades making whisker formation an egregious problem. The work will integrate research and graduate student training at New Mexico Tech and Washington State University by fostering discovery, interactions with the industry, dissemination of results in conferences, as well as mentoring of undergraduate and high school students. It will provide students with hands-on experience in an industrially relevant technology, where materials processing, microstructure, mechanics, and thermodynamics are all tied together in a single problem of world-wide impact.

por.por_cntn:
This project has been a collaborative activity between New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology (New Mexico Tech, PI: Dr. Bhaskar Majumdar) and Washington State University (WSU, Co-PI: Dr. Indranath Dutta).

The primary goal of this work was to develop physics and mechanism based strategies to mitigate Sn whisker growth on electroplated electronic lead-frames without the addition of Pb. Notably, Sn whiskers are typically 1-2 micrometers in diameter (about 30 to 80 times less than the diameter of the human hair) and a few hundred micrometers to several millimeters long. They have been known to cause electrical short circuits between neighboring lines and circuitry in aerospace, nuclear and industrial applications worth millions of dollars of damages, including failure of the Toyota accelerator pedal. Pb additions of a few percent have been known to mitigate Sn whiskers. However, because of environmental regulations in US, Europe and other countries, there has been a major push to develop Pb-free Sn alternatives for electronic packaging technology – including printed circuit boards, electronic chip level interconnects, solder bumps for example in cell phones, and optoelectronic applications. We have demonstrated that addition of about 5 – 10 atomic percent In to Sn electrodeposits completely eliminates Sn whiskers, and thus represents a major success of this NSF program.

The mechanisms responsible for whisker mitigation was investigated in detail, and a primary mechanism is shown, from surface studies (Auger and XPS), to be related to defects in the 4 nm oxide film, such that the defective surface and near-surface region (up to 20 nm deep) can serve to supply vacancies that can lead to compressive stress relaxation in the tin film. Notably, this compressive stress is the major driver for whisker formation and growth. Initially, heat treated multilayered Sn-In-Sn and Sn-Sn-Sn films of 1-2 micrometer thick were investigated. Later, Sn-In co-deposition baths were developed and two US Provisional Patent Applications on these baths have been filed (one each from NMT and WSU).

Microstructural examination using focused ion beam (FIB) cross-sectioning demonstrated predominantly columnar grain structure in 1-2 micron thick electroplated films, whereas it was a mixture of mostly columnar and some equiaxed type of grains at 3 microns thickness. In all cases, whisker mitigation was observed. A second potential mechanism is related to a reduced reaction at the Cu-substrate/Sn-In interface (forming Cu-Sn and Cu-In intermetallics), thereby reducing the source of reaction induced compressive stress generation in the films. This needs further work.

The research has resulted in 5 journal publications and a number of conference proceedings and presentations at major meetings, meant to disseminate the results. The investigators are in discussion with a number of companies to license the product. The electrodeposition facilities created under this program at New Mexico Tech, a Hispanic Serving Institution in an EPSCoR jurisdiction, will aid future undergraduate and graduate students to learn controlled electroplating, especially for alloy deposits that need various organic additives. Simultaneously, efforts to control texture of electroplatings of various alloys are under development and can have major implications in patent disclosure and licensing.

Optimization of Sn-In co-deposition parameters, and a better understanding of the local microstructure and mechanisms are recommended as part of future work.


Last Modified: 01/12/2018
Modified by: Bhaskar S Majumdar
